facts.text: Two criminal appeals disposed of by Calcutta High Court.
High Court set aside conviction under section 302 IPC and award of death sentence.
High Court remitted the matter to the trial judge for de novo trial on finding that trial judge committed serious error in mentioning the time and place of occurrence in the charge framed.
The charge indicates more or less with precision, the date and place when the alleged offence was committed.
Accused has never made any grievance with regard to the defect in the charge before the learned sessions judge.
It is a case of death reference.
Charges framed as shown at pages 5-6 of the paper book.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in setting aside the conviction and sentence and remitting for de novo trial on ground of defect in framing of charge regarding time and place of occurrence.

petitioner_arguments.text: Conclusion of the High Court is erroneous both in law and on facts.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Chittaranjan Das v. State of West Bengal

petitioner_arguments.text: Factual charge indicates more or less with precision, the date and place when the alleged offence was committed.
Accused never made any grievance with regard to the defect in the charge before the sessions judge.

respondent_arguments.text: In a case where death sentence has been referred to the High Court for confirmation, it should not be treated to be an appeal but in continuation of the trial and therefore the appellate court would be justified in looking into the charge framed and find out whether such charge could really prejudice the accused or not.

court_reasoning.text: Object of framing a charge as engrafted in the Code of Criminal Procedure is to give a clear idea of what the accused is being tried for and what are the essential facts he is required to meet in the trial.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unless and until the charge framed could be said to be such that the accused was misled or that such framing of charge has really caused any prejudice in the defence of the accused, the appellate court would not be justified in interfering with the conviction and sentence on the ground of so called defect in the framing of charge.

court_reasoning.text: The decision relied upon by the learned A.S.G. squarely supports this conclusion of ours.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Having regard to the charges framed in this case, as shown at pages 5-6 of the paper book, and the impugned judgment of the Calcutta High Court, the High Court was totally in error in setting aside the conviction and the sentence awarded by the Sessions Judge and in remitting the matter to the Sessions Judge for de novo trial.

holdings.text: High Court was totally in error in setting aside the conviction and sentence and remitting for de novo trial.
Set aside the impugned judgment of the Calcutta High Court and remit criminal appeal Nos. 203 and 232 of 1999 to the High Court for re-disposal in accordance with law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chittaranjan Das v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Law laid down supports that unless charge causes prejudice, no interference with conviction.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under this section set aside by High Court

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Object of framing a charge engrafted in the Code

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside the impugned judgment of the Calcutta High Court and remitted criminal appeal Nos. 203 and 232 of 1999 to the High Court for re-disposal in accordance with law. High Court directed to take up the case immediately after pooja vacation before a bench where any of the learned judges who passed the impugned order would not be a member.
outcome.relief_granted: Remitted appeals to High Court for fresh disposal
